feed.title: Game Review: Mario Kart 7
feed.subtitle: Mario Kart 7 challenges the notion that game consoles are on their way out.

This is not only due to attracting a following through multiplayer mayhem, but providing a thrilling go-cart experience for Nintendo's home and portable consoles.

category.term: 317~Nintendo Co. Ltd.~Disneyland Resort~Matterhorn~The Walt Disney Company
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
There’s some school of thought that the portable game console is on its last legs because of the smart phone boom.

Will people play $40 for a game on a console when they can play Angry Birds, Cut the Rope or Fruit Ninja for less than $5.

If there’s any game that can challenge that it’s Mario Kart 7 for the Nintendo 3Ds.

This is a classic game that has always been a blockbuster on any platform.

For those who aren’t aware, Mario Kart is a fantastical racing game using the classic Nintendo characters.

There are all manner of amazing tracks in classic and new Nintendo settings, and all sorts of karts in which to race. You start off with eight characters to choose from but there are 17 in total once you unlock them all. With mirrored tracks you have 32 to conquer, with some classic and some new to entice you.

This is classic racing that you’re going to love but there’s a healthy dose of new things that make it a wonderful gaming experience.

For starters, there’s the 3D effects. This game looks way better on a small, portable game machine than it did on the old Nintendo 64. Add in the three-dimensional graphics and you really have a better visual experience.

The next biggest change is the power-up system. In Mario Kart there’s been no end to the frustration of being in a tight race near the end of the course and having a shell come from nowhere and knock you into 6th place.

Now there are actually defensive power ups so you can guard yourself against such attacks, though if you’re way ahead in first place you’ll still fall victim to the cheapest tactic in video games, attack of the blue shell

The best powerup to get is now the Tanooki Tail, that swats away shells and also can take out another kart if they get too close.

There’s’ also the Fireflower that will knock foes back a bit, or if you get the old shells you can always save them, not shoot them and use them as shields.

The biggest new “addition” though is clearly the hang glider. You can fully customize your cart, either with the stock options or upgrades you earn from collecting coins. When you hit blue launch pads you can deploy your hang glider and fly above the course, collecting other items in the clouds and even finding short cuts. You may have lots of fun exploring and gliding, but for the most part you’re going to have to get down on the ground to compete as time in the air will, er, hang you up from really getting into first place.

You can also race underwater for the first time which adds a nice twist to the game as the physics effect of being underwater is very well done.

Again, this game is raced on a variety of courses in three classes, 50 cc, 100 cc and 150 cc. I’d argue the courses are full of more peril, so you have to be careful with your speed, it only takes one or two miscalculated turns and plunges off cliffs to ruin your race.

Coins are also key in that you can spend them to upgrade, but also the more you have the faster you go, and you need to consider your brake more in this version of Mario Kart than ever before.

And the powerslide system is a little easier this time around too as that’s been tweaked.

The best part of MK 7 though is racing against foes, either friends locally or online if you hook up via wi-fi.

The game moves quickly with no lag, technically Mario Kart 7 plays as precisely as any I’ve played before and offers enough new stuff to really appeal to old players and new ones alike.

Rating: E for Everyone

What’s right: Hang gliders offer a new way to play, great characters, wonderful course design.

What’s wrong: Still subject to the cheap powerup hit at the expense of driving skill.

Numb Thumb: Graphics A; Gameplay B; Control A; Value B. Overall a B+ on the Numb Thumb.

Disneyland Adventures for Kinect

This is one of the more intriguing titles I have come across in motion gaming. For the Xbox 360 but requiring the Kinect peripheral, this game puts you in the middle of the Disney universe, literally.

Using the motion sensor you navigate tasks, games and rides right in the middle of a virtual replica of Disneyland.

After you start the game at the outside of the park and create a character in your own likeness, you move through the park and interact with all the characters.

If you have ever been to Disneyland, you’ll marvel at how accurate this is, as all the stores, all the cafés, all the rides are exactly where they are in “real life”.

That’s sort of the overarching frame of the game, where you interact with the characters, meet Mickey and he’ll ask you to go and take pictures of all the other characters, or collect their autographs.

Find them and they might refuse their picture until you do something for them, like Donald has lost his hat and you have to go find it on the Matterhorn.

Here’s where Disneyland Adventures takes a cool twist. The rides are nothing like their real life counterparts, but follow that theme.

So the Thunder Mountain Railroad has you chasing a runaway train to stop it from crashing at the end of the track. You use the motion sensor to move, jump, duck, collect so you can get to the front of the train before it crashes.

The Matterhorn sees you fighting Yetis, skiing down steep caverns and getting in snowball fights.

It’s all very well done.

There are some control issues with the motion sensor still, and for younger players they may get frustrated with the operation, but for older players, say 6 and up, if they’re going to Disneyland, or have just been, this will be a magnificent way for them to enjoy the experience regardless.

There’s a lot to see and do here, but it’s more the possibility I see of exploring real places in a virtual landscape when I look at Disneyland Adventures.

Rating: E for Everyone.

What’s right: Amazing detail in replicating the park, fun games and tasks in the ride portion.

What’s wrong: Control is still a bit fussy, will challenge younger players.

Numb Thumb: Graphics A; Control C+; Value B; Gameplay C+. Overall a B on the Numb Thumb.

pchapman@theprovince.com

Twitter: @paulc14

link.title: Power Play: Battlefield 3 a compelling multiplayer shooter

link.Abstract: How much would you pay for imaginary clothes? How about more than $2 billion?
link.title: Power Play: Real money made in fantasy gaming world

link.Abstract: The latest entry in the Legend of Zelda series, Skyward Sword precedes the events of Ocarina of Time. This time, Link is a youth that has been born and raised in Skyloft, a series of islands floating above the clouds. Leading an otherwise ordinary life, Link soon discovers a magical sword, which transports him to a land beneath the clouds, which is inhabited by evil forces. There he must rescue Zelda, a childhood friend who has been swept away by a mysterious Tornado and is being hunted by a demon lord.
link.title: Video: Everything You Should Know About The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword

entry.title: Game review: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3

link.Abstract: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is deservedly one of the most demanded games this season and well worth getting.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation is one of the most in-demand shooter games this season.
link.title: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3

link.Abstract: Picking-up immediately following the events of Modern Warfare 2, the Russian Federation has begun intensifying their invasion of the United States of America. They have also begun invading Europe, England, France and Germany, spurring you to fight for the fate of the free world. A direct sequel, this entry features the return of Task Force 141, who are on the run after killing rogue U.S Army Lieutenant Gerald Shepherd.
link.title: Video: 7 Things You Should Know About Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3

entry.title: Power Play: Battlefield 3 a compelling multiplayer shooter

link.Abstract: Making a big-budget, first-person shooter must be one of the most daunting tasks in video games today.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Battlefield 3
link.title: Battlefield 3

link.Abstract: Set in the year 2014, Battlefield 3 has players take on the role of US Marine Corps soldiers as they are deployed near the Iraq-Iran border. There, players are tasked with combating the People’s Liberation and Resistance. Working in a five-man squad, you must locate, find and safely return a US team that was investigating a possible chemical weapons site, before their location was taken control of by hostile forces. However, things quickly escalate to an attack on New York City. The eleventh installment in the franchise, this game has the greatest production values and most thrilling multi-player experience yet.
link.title: Video: 7 Things You Should Know Battlefield 3
